awd_titl_txt: Computational and Experimental Characterization of Twin-twin Interactions in Hexagonal Metals
awd_abstract_narration:
Hexagonal metals, such as magnesium and titanium with hexagonal close packed structure, have the potential for increasing the efficiency of fuel consumption because of their superior strength-to-density ratio. In particular, magnesium with a density low enough to make it 35 percent lighter than aluminum and 78 percent lighter than steel is perhaps the most appealing of these lightweight materials. Replacing steel structural materials with magnesium-based materials in automotive applications would boost fuel efficiency by more than 50 percent. However, magnesium's use remains fairly limited because of a gap in the knowledge of a phenomenon called twin-twin interactions. Twins are specific features in hexagonal materials that can occur from the nanoscale to microscale and responsible for what is called deformation twinning, which is a major mode of plasticity in magnesium and responsible for its low strength and poor deformability. This research will focus on understanding the effect of twin-twin interactions on the mechanisms of deformation in magnesium by performing modeling at multiple scales supported by experimental observations. The outcome will be a predictive model that would allow engineers and scientists to optimize the processing routes of hexagonal metals for specific structural and environmental applications. As part of this research, students will be provided an opportunity to be trained at a national laboratory. Undergraduate students from underrepresented groups will be hired as part of the research team, and K-12 students will be exposed to the research through outreach events.

The long-term goal of this research is to establish a research framework for quantitatively characterizing and predicting the twinning induced microstructures and mechanical properties of hexagonal materials. It will link the macroscopic plastic responses to the crystallographic mechanisms causing them, while also accounting for microstructure evolution. To do so, the research team will characterize microstructures of twin-twin boundaries at the atomic level through atomistic simulations and transmission electron microscopes; identify twin-twin boundaries dominated deformation mechanisms at the atomic-/micro-scales by using atomistic simulations and in situ nanomechanical testing in scanning electron microscopies; establish twin-twin interaction models at the meso-scale by combining in situ mechanical testing and finite element analysis, and implement the meso-scale models into macro-scale effective-medium polycrystal plasticity models. The numerical and experimental tools developed through this project will eventually enable design of manufacturing processes for specific structural and environmental applications.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Hexagonal metals, such as magnesium and titanium with hexagonal close packed structure, have the attraction for increasing the efficiency of the fuel consumption and reducing the emission of greenhouse gases because of their superior strength-to-density ratio. Their use remains fairly limited because of a gap in the knowledge regarding deformation twinning, that is a major mode of plastic deformation and responsible for its low strength and poor deformability. During forming processes, multiple twin variants nucleate, grow, and interact to each other. Twin-twin interactions result in the formation of characteristic microstructures, affect the subsequent twinning and de-twinning, and influence twinning-induced strain hardening. A precise understanding of how multiple twin variants interact and affect subsequent deformation has been built through this project, and is highlighted as follows.

We systematically observed and characterized twin-twin interaction induced microstructures in Mg and Ti alloys by using Electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD), such as co-zone and non-cozone twin-twin interactions (Figure 1), twin-grain boundaries interactions, and tension twin - compression twin interactions. More importantly, we developed comprehensive understanding of the mechanisms and mechanics involved in the formation of characteristic twin-twin structures based on topological model, atomistic simulations and finite element analysis.

We proposed a fundamental principle of modified deformation gradient accommodation (m-DGA) for predicting consequent deformation modes associated with the twin-twin interactions, including nucleation mechanisms of sequential or secondary twins and the selection principles of sequential or secondary twin variants associated with twin-twin interactions, and validated the m-DGA principle by statistical analysis of twins in deformed Ti and Mg alloys (Figure 2). The proposed m-DGA principle is also extended to predict sequential twins nucleated at steps of a propagating twin boundary under shock loading.

We systematically studied interactions between dislocations and three-dimensional twins by using defect theory and atomistic simulations. Particularly, we for the first time studied three-dimensional (3D) characters of twins using atomistic simulations, crystallographic analysis and microscopic analysis (Figure 3). We found the reaction processes of dislocation-twin interaction is dependent on the effect of 3D twins on dislocation-twin interactions (Figure 4).

We applied or extended the fundamental understanding of twinning for or into more complex structures and generalized the concept of twinning disconnection to a new type of line defect named coherency disclination dipole (CDD, Figure 5). Such a CDD can glide on twinning plane, resulting in twins. Take a mineral material, labradorite as example, we define and discuss the structure, characters, and role of CDDs in minerals and metals (Figure 6). Further experimental characterization validated our model.

These findings enable engineers and scientists to optimize the forming routes of hexagonal metals for specific structural and environmental applications. In addition, the numerical and experimental tools developed through this project can be applied to study other structural materials that deform by twinning and/or phase transformation beside dislocation slips.


Last Modified: 05/26/2021
Modified by: Jian Wang

  • Figure 2. Shock-induced two types of {10-12} sequential twinning in Ti, EBSD (right) and schematics (left).
    Jian Wang

    Sequential twinning due to twin-twin interactions
  • Figure 3. Schematic and atomistic simulations of interactions between 〈a〉 dislocations on basal or prismatic planes and a three-dimensional {11-22 } compression twin
    Jian Wang
    Public Domain
    Jian Wang
    Dislocations-3D twin interactions
  • Figure 4. (a) The coherent dichromatic pattern. (b) The displacements of atoms. The black and red symbols represent matrix and twin atoms. (c) The initial twin nucleus. (d) and (e) atomic configurations of the twin during growth.
    Jian Wang
    Public Domain
    Jian Wang
    Three dimensional Twins
  • Figure 5. Three types of disclinations. (a) Projected view of a wedge disclination. (b) View of a twist disconnection. (c) View of a coherency disconnection.
    Jian Wang
    Public Domain
    Jian Wang
    Three types of disclinations.
  • Figure 6. (a). Repeat unit of two (001) planes viewed along [-10-1]. (b). Structure of (a) is sheared by b above the twin boundary, but no shuffles are imposed. (c) is the matrix part of the e-cell in the SDC, with b subtracted from (b). (d) HRTEM image of albite twin boundary in low albite.
    Jian Wang
    Public Domain
    Jian Wang
    Twinning in low albite
